Trial_Design.evidence: Patients were assigned randomly to the DNTP group (n = 50) or the LAIP group (n = 50).

Participants.evidence: One hundred patients between 18 and 70 years undergoing elective surgery requiring IJV cannulation were recruited.

Intervention.evidence: This study aims to compare the first-pass success rate of IJV cannulation using the DNTP and long-axis in-plane (LAIP) approaches.

Objective.evidence: This study aims to compare the first-pass success rate of IJV cannulation using the DNTP and long-axis in-plane (LAIP) approaches.

Method_Outcome.evidence: We recorded the first-pass success rate, time to achieve successful cannulation, number of skin punctures, overall success rate within five minutes, and potential complications such as pneumothorax and hematoma.

Randomisation_Allocation.evidence: Patients were assigned randomly to the DNTP group (n = 50) or the LAIP group (n = 50).

Number_Randomised.evidence: Patients were assigned randomly to the DNTP group (n = 50) or the LAIP group (n = 50).

Number_Analysed.evidence: The first pass success rate was higher in the DNTP group (48/50, 96%) as compared to the LAIP group (38/50, 76%, relative risk, 1.67; 95% confidence interval, 0.039-0.707; p = 0.008).

Result_Outcome.evidence: The first pass success rate was higher in the DNTP group (48/50, 96%) as compared to the LAIP group (38/50, 76%, relative risk, 1.67; 95% confidence interval, 0.039-0.707; p = 0.008).

Harms.evidence: No complications like pneumothorax or hematoma were noted in both groups.
